metadata.titleEn: Surface energy balance based global land evapotranspiration (EB-ET 2000-2017)
metadata.description:
Daily and Monthly evapotranspiration (5km x 5km spatial resolution) for global land area was derived from satellite data and a surface energy balance method (EB). The global 5 km daily and monthly ET dataset is produced with the revised SEBS algorithm in Chen et al. 2019 JGR and Chen et al. 2013 (JAMC). For how to obtain seamless daily evaporation data by thermal infrared, please refer to Chen et al. 2021 JGR. This paper also compares different evaporation products. The results show that this product is significantly better than Landflux, GLEAM, MOD16, GLDAS and ERA-Interim products in irrigation area. The downscaling of reanalysis forcing data is detailed in this paper. MODIS LST, NDVI, Global forest height, GlobAlbedo, GLASS LAI have been used in this ET calculation. The ET dataset will be updated to near-present with the availability of input dataset. The global 5 km sensible heat flux, net radiation, latent heat flux will be open with the email contact with Dr. Xuelong Chen. 

Daily ET File name: 20001201-ET-V1.mat, 2000-year, 12-month,01-day, ET-Evapotranspiration, V1-version 1;unit: mm/day (unit8 need transfer to single or double and should be divided by 10);data type: unit8 was used to save the disk space, 255 is used for ocean and water body pixels.
Monthly ET File name: ETm200012-ET-V1.mat, 2000-year, 12-month, ET-Evapotranspiration, V1-version 1;unit: mm/month (int16 need transfer to single or double and should be divided by 10);data type: int16 was used to save the disk space, 0 is used for ocean and water body pixels.

The daily ET dataset is produced with a similar method and satellite data as in Chen, X., et al., 2014: Development of a 10 year (2001–2010) 0.1° dataset of land-surface energy balance for mainland China, Atmos. Chem. Phys., 14, 13097–13117, doi:10.5194/acp-14-13097-2014. The calculation of roughness length and kB_1 for global land were updated by the method in Chen, X., et al, 2019, A Column Canopy‐Air Turbulent Diffusion Method for Different Canopy Structures, Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, 2019.01.15, 124. Most of the satellite input data were from MODIS. Meteorological data was from ERA-Interim. Global canopy height information was derived from GLAS and MODIS NDVI. 

The daily ET has a mean bias (MB) of 0.04 mm/day, RMSE is 1.56 (±0.25) mm/day.

background: Because of the elevation of the Tibetan Plateau, energy and water are exchanged between the surface and the middle troposphere above it. The growing interest in the interaction between atmosphere and plateau surface is driven by the realization that the thermal effects of the plateau may influence atmospheric circulation in the Northern Hemisphere (Tao and Ding 1981; Wang et al. 2011). Conventional meteorological techniques that employ point measurements to estimate the components of the surface energy balance represent work on a local scale (Su et al. 2006). Remote sensing enables us to estimate surface fluxes from local to regional scales and offers the possibility to derive the regional distribution of land surface heat fluxes over little-instrumented and sparsely populated areas. Recent studies have explored remote sensing approaches to estimate the regional distribution of surface heat fluxes (Ma et al. 2003, 2008b, 2011). The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) developed by Su (2002) can estimate turbulent heat fluxes from point to continental scale with reasonable accuracy using satellite and meteorological data (Su et al. 2005; Oku et al. 2007, etc.). The roughness height for heat transfer z0h needs to be determined to accurately calculate the sensible heat flux by means of the Monin–Obukhov similarity theory (MOST) and SEBS. The scalar roughness height for heat transfer can be derived from z0h = z0m/exp(kB21), where z0m is the roughness height for momentum transfer and kB21 is the excess resistance for heat transportation, with k again being the von Kármán constant and B21 being the Stanton number. SEBS has been widely used to estimate the surface energy balance and evapotranspiration in different areas; further analysis of the uncertainties has been limited, however.
research objective: In this study, the performance of the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) has been tested and evaluated for typical land surfaces on the Tibetan Plateau on the basis of time series of observations at four sites with bare soil, sparse canopy, dense canopy, and snow surface, respectively. In this study, we first tested at four different land cover units whether SEBS driven by boundary layer meteorological measurements, as opposed to tower-based flux measurements, can be used to derive items of surface energy balance over the Tibetan Plateau. Then, we evaluated the impact of varying parameters on H estimates from SEBS and used this information to try to identify the causes of SEBS’s biases. We then improved the turbulent heat parameterization in SEBS—to be specific, the equation for kB21.
challenges: The lack of observational datasets on the interactions between the whole plateau and the atmosphere above makes it difficult for us to quantitatively analyze the variation in energy and water exchanges in this region. Although significant progress has been made, further efforts are needed to improve the accuracy of SEBS over the Tibetan Plateau regions (Su et al. 2006). Few formulas are able to describe the observed diurnal variation in kB21 over the Tibetan Plateau (Ma et al. 2009). The sensitivity of sensible heat flux estimates from SEBS has not yet been fully examined.
methods: The high-frequency turbulence data were processed to produce half-hourly fluxes. Calibrations of the eddy-covariance signals were also executed. Meteorological and soil-observation data were sampled every 10 min. All datasets were then resampled to 30-min intervals by nearest interpolation method. The TK2 software package (Mauder and Foken 2011) was used here to process the turbulent data of QOMS/CAS, Nam Co, and Linzhi. The spike-detection algorithm of Vickers and Mahrt (1997) was used to remove physically or electronically unfeasible values in the high-frequency turbulent data. The time delay between sonic-anemometer (CSAT3) and gas-analyzer (LI-7500) signals was eliminated by maximizing covariance. Tilt correction was done with the planar-fit method (Wilczak et al. 2001). Correction of spectral loss was done according to the Moore (1986) method. The sonic temperature was converted into actual temperature. The Webb–Pearman–Leuning (WPL) corrections (Webb et al. 1980) were also performed in the process. The SEBS model was run to produce accurate sensible heat flux results, which was achieved by using available observational variables.
dataset: Data used in this paper were collected at four research stations on the Tibetan Plateau: Qomolangma Station for Atmospheric and Environmental Observation and Research from the Chinese Academy of Sciences (hereinafter QOMS/CAS), Nam Co Monitoring and Research Station for Multisphere Interactions (hereinafter Nam Co), Linzhi Station for Alpine Environment Observation and Research (hereinafter Linzhi station), and Maqu station. The dataset of the QOMS/CAS station consists of surface radiation components (Kipp and Zonen, Inc., model CNR-1); vertical profiles of air temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction (Vaisala, Inc., model MILOS520); and turbulent fluxes. A dataset covering 1 April–31 December 2007 was used in this paper. The meteorological measurements (sensor height, depth, and types) taken at Nam Co and QOMS/CAS are the same. A dataset covering 25 February–30 October 2007 was used from this site for the study. Meteorological measurements from each station used in this study have been listed in Table 2.
findings: Both under- and overestimation at low and high sensible heat fluxes by SEBS was discovered. The results show that the revised model performs better than the original model.

background: Evapotranspiration (ET) is the turbulent flux of water vapor from the land surface into the air, including soil evaporation, interception from the canopy, and transpiration through the stomata of plants. ET is modulated by surface turbulence (Su et al., 2001), boundary-layer processes (Kim & Entekhabi, 1998), and biophysics (Verhoef & Egea, 2014). Various ET models that apply different physical process parameterizations have been developed to estimate land surface ET. Different models have resulted in large differences in ET estimation at the continental to global scale (Jiménez et al., 2011; Mueller et al., 2011). Variation among global ET estimates indicate a 50% uncertainty in the annual mean value (Su & Feng, 2015; Vinukollu).
research objective: Currently available evapotranspiration (ET) products have not provided us with an accurate estimation for global irrigated land area. Thermal energy balance (EB) model has the potential to solve this problem. The accurate estimation of aerodynamic resistances is a major complication in most remote sensing ET models.
challenges: The estimation of surface resistance is a major issue in most remote sensing ET models, especially the estimation of canopy and aerodynamic resistances. In addition, most estimation approaches do not address the dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance with roughness and stability.
methods: A method was developed to more realistically depict dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance. In order to estimate global ET and land surface fluxes for all weather conditions, Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) Aqua and Terra land surface temperature fields were combined and a nearest-evaporative-fraction gap-filling method was merged into the EB model. A global ET product covering the period 2003–2017 was produced using the EB model. By combining thermal and optional information from MODIS satellites and surface meteorological forcing data from ERA-Interim reanalysis data, the EB model provides a 5 × 5 km resolution estimate of daily ET without spatio-temporal gaps at the global scale.
findings: Analysis of global precipitation minus ET demonstrated that EB ET has a relatively higher potential for agriculture water resource management than currently available global ET products, such as Landflux, GLEAM, MOD16, GLDAS, and ERA-Interim ET.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'aerodynamic resistance' in remote sensing evapotranspiration models?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic resistance refers to the resistance encountered by water vapor as it moves from the land surface to the atmosphere in remote sensing evapotranspiration models. The accurate estimation of aerodynamic resistances is a major challenge in ET models, as it is influenced by factors like roughness and stability, and it is crucial for producing accurate land surface flux estimates.

Definition.Question: What does 'thermal energy balance (EB) model' imply in the context of global evapotranspiration estimation?
Definition.Answer: The thermal energy balance (EB) model is a method used to estimate global evapotranspiration and land surface fluxes by combining satellite thermal imagery with meteorological data. It addresses the challenge of accurately estimating aerodynamic resistances and provides a high-resolution estimate of daily ET without spatio-temporal gaps. It shows potential for improving water resource management in agriculture compared to other global ET products.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for estimating global evapotranspiration from remote sensing data compare to traditional point measurement techniques in terms of accuracy and applicability across different land surfaces?
Comparison.Answer: Remote sensing methods such as the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) allow for estimation of surface heat fluxes from local to regional scales and have been tested on various land surfaces such as bare soil, sparse canopy, dense canopy, and snow surfaces. These methods offer the advantage of covering large-scale, sparsely populated areas, which is a limitation of traditional point measurement techniques. Traditional techniques provide local scale data, while remote sensing can extend to continental scales.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of estimating aerodynamic resistance in remote sensing ET models differ from those involved in calculating surface resistance?
Comparison.Answer: The estimation of aerodynamic resistance in remote sensing ET models primarily deals with dynamic changes with roughness and stability, which are not adequately addressed in many approaches. In contrast, estimating surface resistance involves complexities in dealing with canopy resistance and its various contributing factors. Both present significant challenges, but aerodynamic resistance is more affected by environmental conditions and requires dynamic modeling.

Interpretation.Question: How can remote sensing techniques be interpreted to enhance the accuracy of surface heat flux estimation over regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing allows for the estimation of surface fluxes across local to regional scales, offering the potential to derive the distribution of land surface heat fluxes in sparsely instrumented areas. The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) leverages satellite and meteorological data to estimate heat fluxes accurately, although uncertainties remain, particularly in regions like the Tibetan Plateau where observational datasets are limited.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges and considerations emerge when inferring aerodynamic resistances in remote sensing ET models?
Interpretation.Answer: The estimation of surface resistance, particularly canopy and aerodynamic resistances, poses significant challenges in remote sensing ET models. Most approaches struggle with capturing dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance due to roughness and stability, complicating accurate ET estimation.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be inferred from the comparative performance of different global ET products in managing agricultural water resources?
Interpretation.Answer: The EB ET model has shown a higher potential for agricultural water management compared to other global ET products like Landflux, GLEAM, MOD16, GLDAS, and ERA-Interim. This is inferred from the analysis of global precipitation minus ET, suggesting that the EB ET model provides a more accurate estimation of water availability for agriculture.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) to either overestimate or underestimate sensible heat fluxes in certain regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Both under- and overestimation at low and high sensible heat fluxes by SEBS have been discovered. The sensitivity of sensible heat flux estimates from SEBS has not yet been fully examined, which contributes to these discrepancies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is accurately estimating aerodynamic resistances a significant challenge in remote sensing evapotranspiration models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The estimation of surface resistance, particularly canopy and aerodynamic resistances, poses a major challenge in remote sensing ET models. Most estimation approaches fail to address the dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance with roughness and stability, complicating accurate ET estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of dynamic aerodynamic resistance models impact the reliability of evapotranspiration data in remote sensing applications?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using dynamic aerodynamic resistance models improves the reliability of evapotranspiration data by more realistically depicting changes in aerodynamic resistance due to roughness and stability. This addresses a major issue in remote sensing ET models, enhancing the accuracy of global ET estimates for various weather conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing remote sensing techniques to estimate surface fluxes over sparsely populated regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to enable estimation of surface fluxes from local to regional scales, offering the possibility to derive the regional distribution of land surface heat fluxes over little-instrumented and sparsely populated areas. This addresses the lack of observational datasets and helps understand energy and water exchanges in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to ensure the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates when using remote sensing data combined with surface meteorological forcing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates, a method is developed to depict dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance. Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) Aqua and Terra land surface temperature fields are combined, and a nearest-evaporative-fraction gap-filling method is merged into the energy balance (EB) model. This process involves combining thermal and optional information from MODIS satellites and surface meteorological forcing data from ERA-Interim reanalysis data to provide a 5 × 5 km resolution estimate of daily ET without spatio-temporal gaps at the global scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can high-frequency turbulence data be processed to produce accurate half-hourly flux measurements in a study on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: High-frequency turbulence data can be processed to produce accurate half-hourly flux measurements through several steps: calibrating eddy-covariance signals, sampling meteorological and soil-observation data every 10 minutes, and resampling all datasets to 30-minute intervals using the nearest interpolation method. Additional steps involve using the TK2 software package to process turbulent data, applying a spike-detection algorithm to remove unfeasible values, eliminating time delays between signals by maximizing covariance, performing tilt correction with the planar-fit method, and correcting for spectral loss using the Moore method. Sonic temperature conversion and the Webb–Pearman–Leuning (WPL) corrections are also performed.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific challenges must be addressed when estimating surface resistance in remote sensing evapotranspiration models, and how can these be overcome?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A major challenge in estimating surface resistance in remote sensing evapotranspiration models is accurately estimating canopy and aerodynamic resistances, particularly regarding their dynamic changes with roughness and stability. This can be overcome by developing methods that realistically depict these dynamic changes, which involves integrating satellite-derived thermal information and meteorological data to provide comprehensive and continuous global ET estimates.

Enablement.Question: What meteorological and satellite data integration techniques enable the accurate estimation of land surface energy balance and evapotranspiration at a regional scale?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of satellite data and meteorological measurements, as seen with the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS), enables the estimation of land surface energy balance and evapotranspiration. The use of thermal infrared data, MODIS LST, NDVI, and global forest height information aids in producing these estimates without spatio-temporal gaps, allowing for accurate assessments at regional scales.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of remote sensing technologies enable the overcoming of challenges related to the estimation of aerodynamic and surface resistances in evapotranspiration models?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing technologies, like those used in the EB model, allow for the dynamic depiction of changes in aerodynamic resistance, which is a major challenge in ET models. By combining thermal information from MODIS satellites with meteorological data from ERA-Interim reanalysis, these technologies enable the accurate estimation of ET without gaps due to their ability to address changes in roughness and stability.

Enablement.Question: What are the enabling conditions that facilitate the collection of high-frequency turbulence data for the accurate determination of surface fluxes in sparsely populated areas?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of high-frequency turbulence data in sparsely populated areas is enabled by deploying research stations equipped with necessary instruments, such as sonic anemometers and gas analyzers. These stations, like those on the Tibetan Plateau, provide crucial meteorological and soil-observation data, which are processed using techniques such as spike-detection algorithms, tilt correction, and spectral loss correction to produce accurate surface flux measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately estimating surface resistance in remote sensing evapotranspiration models?
Expectation.Answer: The estimation of surface resistance in remote sensing ET models is complicated due to the dynamic changes in canopy and aerodynamic resistances, which are impacted by factors such as roughness and stability. Many models do not adequately address these variations, leading to challenges in achieving accurate estimations.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the discrepancies observed between different global evapotranspiration estimates?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies between global ET estimates can arise from the varying physical process parameterizations applied by different ET models. These differences can significantly affect ET estimation at large scales, with some studies indicating a 50% uncertainty in the annual mean value, suggesting that the models' approaches to representing surface turbulence, boundary-layer processes, and biophysics can lead to significant variations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the SEBS model overestimate or underestimate sensible heat fluxes compared to observations?
Expectation.Answer: The SEBS model may overestimate or underestimate sensible heat fluxes due to the challenges in accurately parameterizing turbulent heat fluxes and the uncertainties related to the roughness height for heat transfer. These issues, along with the limited examination of the sensitivity of sensible heat flux estimates, can lead to biases in the model's predictions.

Judgmental.Question: What are the complexities associated with accurately estimating aerodynamic resistances in remote sensing ET models, and how might these challenges impact the quality of global ET datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The estimation of aerodynamic resistances is a major complication in remote sensing ET models. Most approaches do not address the dynamic changes in aerodynamic resistance with roughness and stability, which can affect the accuracy of global ET datasets. The EB model attempts to solve this by including a method for more realistically depicting these dynamic changes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential benefits and limitations of using the SEBS model for estimating surface energy balance and evapotranspiration over sparsely populated areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The SEBS model can estimate turbulent heat fluxes from point to continental scale using satellite and meteorological data, which is beneficial for sparsely populated areas like the Tibetan Plateau. However, the model's performance can be affected by uncertainties in parameterization, such as the roughness height for heat transfer. Further analysis is needed to improve its accuracy in these regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how aerodynamic resistances are accurately estimated in remote sensing evapotranspiration models.
Assertion.Answer: The estimation of aerodynamic resistances is a major challenge in most remote sensing ET models, and a specific method was developed to more realistically depict dynamic changes in these resistances. This involves combining thermal and optional information from MODIS satellites and surface meteorological data to provide a detailed estimate of aerodynamic resistance.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the significance of using thermal energy balance models for estimating evapotranspiration on a global scale.
Assertion.Answer: Thermal energy balance models have the potential to accurately estimate ET, especially for global irrigated land areas. These models address complications in ET estimation by accurately estimating aerodynamic resistances and using thermal data from MODIS satellites, providing a higher potential for agricultural water resource management compared to other global ET products.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing approaches can derive regional distributions of land surface heat fluxes with reasonable accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing enables the estimation of surface fluxes from local to regional scales. The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) model, in particular, can estimate turbulent heat fluxes using satellite and meteorological data, and it has been widely used to estimate surface energy balance and evapotranspiration, despite some uncertainties.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of different remote sensing approaches in estimating regional distributions of surface heat fluxes and their potential challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Recent studies have used remote sensing approaches to estimate the regional distribution of surface heat fluxes, such as the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS). SEBS can estimate turbulent heat fluxes with reasonable accuracy using satellite and meteorological data. However, challenges include the need for accurate determination of roughness height for heat transfer and the sensitivity of sensible heat flux estimates. Further efforts are needed to improve the accuracy of SEBS, especially in areas like the Tibetan Plateau where observational datasets are limited.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used in processing high-frequency turbulence data for calculating surface energy balance components.
Request/Directive.Answer: High-frequency turbulence data are processed to produce half-hourly fluxes, with calibrations of eddy-covariance signals executed. Meteorological and soil-observation data are sampled every 10 minutes and resampled to 30-minute intervals using the nearest interpolation method. The TK2 software package is used to process the turbulent data, with spike-detection algorithms and corrections for time delay, tilt, and spectral loss applied. The Webb–Pearman–Leuning corrections are performed, and the SEBS model is run using available observational variables to produce accurate sensible heat flux results.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential for improving global evapotranspiration (ET) product accuracy through advanced modeling techniques and data integration.
Request/Directive.Answer: Currently available ET products face challenges in accurately estimating global irrigated land areas. A thermal energy balance (EB) model has been developed to address this issue, with improvements made in estimating aerodynamic resistances. The EB model combines MODIS Aqua and Terra land surface temperature fields with surface meteorological forcing data from ERA-Interim reanalysis to provide a global ET product with a 5 × 5 km resolution. The analysis indicates that this EB ET product has a higher potential for agricultural water resource management compared to existing global ET products like Landflux, GLEAM, MOD16, GLDAS, and ERA-Interim.
